verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: The prophet Jeremiah continues to receive the word directly from God, a sign of his special calling and mission as a spokesman for the LORD.

verses.text: "Go and proclaim in the hearing of Jerusalem, ‘This is what the LORD says: I remember the devotion of your youth, your love as a bride, how you followed me in the wilderness, in a land not sown.
verses.comment: God recalls Israel’s faithfulness at the start of their relationship, comparing it to young love. This sets up the theme of marital covenant alluded to by the prophets, later echoed in New Testament images of Christ and His Church (Eph. 5:25-27).

verses.text: Israel was holy to the LORD, the firstfruits of his harvest. All who ate of it became guilty; disaster came upon them,’ declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Firstfruits means Israel was set apart and precious to God. Those who harmed Israel faced judgment—a foreshadowing of a people set apart and under God's protection.

verses.text: Hear the word of the LORD, O house of Jacob, and all the families of the house of Israel.
verses.comment: A call to the whole people of Israel to listen, emphasizing the unity of God’s people as one family bound by His covenant.

verses.text: This is what the LORD says: What fault did your fathers find in me that they went far from me and followed worthless things, becoming worthless themselves?
verses.comment: Idolatry makes the worshiper like the idol—worthless and empty. This process of becoming what one worships is a warning in both Old and New Testaments (Ps. 115:4-8).

verses.text: They did not say, ‘Where is the LORD who brought us up from the land of Egypt, who led us through the wilderness, a land of deserts and pits, a land of drought and deep darkness, a land that no one passes through, where no one lives?’
verses.comment: Forgetting God’s mighty acts—a common pattern seen in Psalm 106 and a warning against spiritual forgetfulness.

verses.text: I brought you into a plentiful land to eat its fruit and its good things. But when you entered, you defiled my land and made my inheritance an abomination.
verses.comment: The promised land is God’s inheritance, entrusted to the people for faithful stewardship—a theme later expanded by Jesus’ parables (Matt. 21:33-41).

verses.text: The priests did not say, ‘Where is the LORD?’ Those who handle the law did not know me; the shepherds rebelled against me; the prophets prophesied by Baal and walked after things that do not profit.
verses.comment: Even religious leaders failed in their duties—an important warning of the need for holy leaders and true teachers throughout salvation history.

verses.text: "Therefore I still contend with you,” declares the LORD, “and with your children’s children I will contend.
verses.comment: Divine chastisement continues across generations when there is no repentance, yet such contention is also mercy, calling God’s people to return.

verses.text: For cross to the coasts of Cyprus and see, or send to Kedar and examine with care; see if there has been such a thing:
verses.comment: A challenge to compare Israel’s betrayal with the faithfulness of even the pagan nations; Israel alone abandons her God.

verses.text: Has a nation changed its gods, even though they are not gods? But my people have changed their glory for that which does not profit.
verses.comment: Israel’s exchanging the true God for idols prefigures humanity’s recurring temptation to prefer created things over the Creator—see Romans 1:23.

verses.text: Be appalled, O heavens, at this; be shocked and utterly desolate, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Creation itself is called as a witness to Israel’s unfaithfulness, highlighting the cosmic dimension of sin.

verses.text: For my people have committed two evils: they have forsaken me, the fountain of living water, and dug out cisterns for themselves, broken cisterns that cannot hold water.
verses.comment: Forsaking God is trading the source of life for empty substitutes. Jesus will later present Himself as the living water, fulfilling this prophecy.

verses.text: Is Israel a servant, a slave by birth? Why then has he become a prey?
verses.comment: Israel is not meant for slavery but sonship. Their enslavement by foreign nations is a result of abandoning their unique calling as God’s children.

verses.text: Lions have roared against him, they have raised their voice; they have made his land a waste; his cities are burned and uninhabited.
verses.comment: The image of lions and devastation points to judgment by foreign powers, a consequence of Israel’s infidelity.

verses.text: Even the people of Memphis and Tahpanhes have shaved the crown of your head.
verses.comment: Egyptian cities symbolize foreign domination and dishonor—a sign of Israel’s loss of dignity when trusting human powers over God.

verses.text: Have you not brought this upon yourself by forsaking the LORD your God, when he led you in the way?
verses.comment: The consequences of sin are portrayed as self-inflicted, resulting from the rejection of God’s way.

verses.text: And now, what do you gain by going to Egypt to drink the waters of the Nile? Or by going to Assyria to drink the waters of the Euphrates?
verses.comment: Seeking help from foreign nations instead of God is spiritually dangerous—idolatry and misplaced trust cut off the blessings meant for God’s people.

verses.text: Your own evil will discipline you, and your apostasy will reprove you. Know and see that it is evil and bitter for you to forsake the LORD your God; the fear of me is not in you, declares the Lord GOD of hosts.
verses.comment: Spiritual consequences follow apostasy, highlighting the natural law of sowing and reaping. The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom (Prov. 1:7).

verses.text: For long ago you broke your yoke and tore off your bonds, and you said, ‘I will not serve!’ Yes, on every high hill and under every green tree you bowed yourself like a prostitute.
verses.comment: Idolatry is called spiritual adultery—an image used throughout Scripture and fulfilled in the New Testament’s call to radical faithfulness to Christ alone.

verses.text: Yet I had planted you as a choice vine, holy and of pure seed. How then have you turned degenerate and become a wild vine?
verses.comment: God’s planting imagery anticipates Jesus’ teaching, ‘I am the true vine’ (John 15:1). Israel’s calling is to remain in the source of holiness.

verses.text: Though you wash yourself with lye and use much soap, the stain of your guilt is still before me, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: No human means can remove the stain of sin—hinting at the need for a deeper cleansing only God can provide.

verses.text: How can you say, ‘I am not defiled, I have not gone after the Baals’? See your way in the valley; acknowledge what you have done. You are a swift young camel running here and there.
verses.comment: Self-deception in sin is exposed; the image of the wandering camel shows restlessness when separated from the right path.

verses.text: A wild donkey accustomed to the wilderness, in the heat of her desire, she sniffs the wind. Who can restrain her lust? All who seek her will not grow weary; in her mating season they will find her.
verses.comment: Idolatry leads to unrestrained passion—language often used to describe unchecked desires and spiritual infidelity.

verses.text: Keep your feet from going unshod and your throat from thirst. But you said, ‘It is hopeless! No, for I have loved strangers, and after them I will go.’
verses.comment: The people’s resignation to their sin reveals the depth of their spiritual brokenness. They pursue lesser loves at the expense of the true covenant relationship.

verses.text: As the thief is ashamed when he is caught, so the house of Israel is put to shame—they, their kings, their officials, their priests, and their prophets.
verses.comment: Guilt spreads throughout the whole community—from leaders down—a theme picked up by Jesus when He warns about the blind leading the blind.

verses.text: They say to a tree, ‘You are my father,’ and to a stone, ‘You gave me birth.’ For they have turned their back to me and not their face. But in the time of their trouble they say, ‘Arise and save us!’
verses.comment: Turning to idols (created things) instead of the Creator is at the heart of all apostasy. Yet in distress, the people return to God, showing the enduring hope for repentance.

verses.text: But where are your gods you made for yourself? Let them arise, if they can save you, in your time of trouble! For you have as many gods as you have towns, O Judah.
verses.comment: The futility of trusting in idols is exposed—no salvation apart from the Lord.

verses.text: Why do you contend with me? All of you have rebelled against me, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: God challenges Israel for arguing against Him; their collective guilt is underlined.

verses.text: In vain have I struck your children; they took no correction. Your own sword devoured your prophets like a destroying lion.
verses.comment: Rejecting discipline and persecuting prophets anticipates how Christ and His apostles would be treated.

verses.text: O generation, consider the word of the LORD. Have I been a wilderness to Israel, or a land of thick darkness? Why then do my people say, ‘We are free; we will come to you no more’?
verses.comment: God’s generosity is questioned by those who desire freedom apart from Him; true freedom is found only in relationship with God.

verses.text: Can a virgin forget her ornaments, or a bride her attire? Yet my people have forgotten me days without number.
verses.comment: Forgetting God is likened to a bride forgetting her wedding dress—a shocking image highlighting the intimate union meant between God and His people.

verses.text: How well you direct your course to seek love! So that even wicked women have taught your ways.
verses.comment: Israel’s relentless pursuit of false loves has made her even more skilled in infidelity—a reversal of her true calling.

verses.text: Also in your skirts is found the lifeblood of the innocent poor; you did not find them breaking in. Yet in spite of all these things,
verses.comment: Guilt for unjust bloodshed adds to Israel’s sins; justice and mercy are inseparable for God’s people.

verses.text: you say, ‘I am innocent; surely his anger has turned from me.’ Behold, I will bring you to judgment for saying, ‘I have not sinned.’
verses.comment: Denial of sin is confronted as the height of spiritual blindness. The New Covenant’s call to confess sin for forgiveness is foreshadowed here.

verses.text: Why do you go about so much, changing your way? You shall be put to shame by Egypt, as you were shamed by Assyria.
verses.comment: Instability and seeking new alliances show the vanity of trusting in anything apart from God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: From there also you shall go out with your hands on your head; for the LORD has rejected those in whom you trust, and you will not prosper by them.
verses.comment: Humiliation is the result of misplaced trust. The chapter ends with a warning, but also sets up the call for a restored trust in God through renewed covenant faithfulness.
